nice.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: They’ve got a very nice house.
Did you have a nice time?
It’s such a nice day (=good weather), why not go for a swim?
One of the nice things about Christmas is having all the family together.
You look nice in that suit.
The house seemed nice and tidy.
nice.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: That’s not a very nice thing to say about your sister!
He told me, in the nicest possible way, that I was interfering too much.
Tim spilt wine all over the sofa, but Martha was very nice about it.
They were very nice to me while I was ill.
It was nice of you to help.
it is nice of somebody (to do something)
nice.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: used to say what you like or what you think would be good or useful
nice.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: It’s quite nice to live so close to work.
I thought it would be a nice idea to send them some flowers.
It would be nice if you could let us know in advance.
‘Would you like a cup of coffee?’ ‘Yes, that’d be nice.’
It would be nice to have a break.
it is nice to do something
nice.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: used in a humorous or angry way when you really think that something or someone is not at all good or pleasant
nice.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: That’s a nice way to treat a friend, I must say!
Well, we’re in a nice mess now.
nice.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: involving a very small difference or detail
nice.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: having high standards of moral and social behaviour
nice.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: What’s a nice girl like you doing in a place like this?
nice.translation[0].note_box[0].items[1]: There are some nice old houses
There are some old nice houses
nice.translation[0].note_box[0].items[2]: I had a nice long sleep
I had a long nice sleep
nice.translation[0].note_box[0].items[3]: You can use nice and followed by another adjective after be
The weather was nice and warm
nice.translation[0].note_box[0].items[4]: Before a noun you must leave out and
nice.translation[0].note_box[1].sections: friendly, kind, or polite. In written and formal English, it is better to use a more specific and interesting adjective than nice
I like Clare – she’s really nice.
It was nice of them to offer to help.
friendly, polite, and easy to talk to – used especially about someone that you do not know very well
I only met her once or twice but she seemed pleasant.
Kylie’s a very caring, sweet person.
It was sweet of you to send me a card.
behaving in a polite and friendly way, which makes people like you and want to do things for you
interesting or amusing in a way that makes people like you – a rather formal word
easy to like and seeming nice and friendly
Bobby was a likeable kid with an angelic face.
having a nice kind character and not getting angry easily
Everyone likes Mike because he’s always so good-natured.
used about someone who you like and admire a lot
All the people I met on the course were lovely.
describing something you like or enjoy
Did you have a nice day?
It was nice to be back home again.
We had a lovely time at the beach.
if something is fun, you enjoy it
We had a very enjoyable evening.
We all had a brilliant time.
used about something that seems pleasant and has a lot of qualities that make you like it
a charming little village in the Italian countryside
I thought the restaurant was rather charming.
There are many delightful walks in the area.
a pleasurable experience or feeling is one that you enjoy
Shopping in the old city can be a pleasurable experience.
nice.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: a city on the Mediterranean coast of France, famous as a fashionable place for tourists to stay, and also a port and industrial area
